Note: Attis is Cybele’s consecrated male—variously conceived as her son or generated from her primal substance, bound to her as a non-reproductive consort, and ritually annihilated through castration and death as a sacrificial embodiment of fertility returned to the earth.

Although Cybele is not named in the Purulli Ritual Instructions, the rites preserve an early Anatolian Mother-goddess complex—centered on maternal authority, seasonal renewal, and earth-bound sovereignty—that later crystallizes in Cybele’s cult.

In the Song of Kumarbi, Hannahanna functions as a primordial maternal authority who stabilizes the cosmic order amid violent male succession struggles, anticipating later Anatolian mother-goddess forms such as Cybele.
Here Hannahanna appears as the primordial maternal authority consulted when divine succession and violence fail, preserving ancient cosmological knowledge that enables the restoration of order.

In the Song of Kumarbi, Kumarbi functions as a transitional deity who violently overthrows the sky-god Anu but fails to establish stable kingship, instead becoming the generative conduit through which the Storm God Teshub is born.
Here Kumarbi functions as a strategic saboteur who weaponizes primordial inertia against divine sovereignty rather than seeking rule himself.
In the Anitta Text, the Storm God of Hatti appears as the divine guarantor of royal authority, invoked to legitimize conquest and enforce curses.
In the Edict of Telipinu, Tarḫunna/Teshub appears as the divine guarantor of lawful kingship, invoked to end cycles of dynastic violence and to legitimize a stable, rule-bound succession.
The Hittite Laws reflect Tarḫunna/Teshub as a silent guarantor of justice, whose mythic sovereignty has been fully absorbed into legal practice.
Here Tarḫunna/Teshub appears as the victorious Storm God whose triumph over chaos is ritually reenacted each spring to restore fertility and reaffirm cosmic order.
The text presents Tarḫunna/Teshub as an emergent sovereign, born through rupture rather than lineage and positioned as the inevitable replacement of Kumarbi’s failed rule.
The Treaty of Kadesh presents Tarḫunna/Teshub as an "international" legal authority, invoked to enforce interstate peace through divine sanction
Here Tarḫunna/Teshub is presented as a god of personal election, whose favor justifies kingship beyond formal succession rules.
The Myth presents Tarḫunna/Teshub as a vulnerable but recoverable sovereign, whose rule depends on continual containment of chaos rather than permanent victory.

Secondary Name: Instructions to Priests and Temple Officials
Note: Here Tarḫunna/Teshub is portrayed as an institutionalized sovereign whose presence is maintained through correct cultic administration.

In the Song of Ullikummi, Tarḫunna/Teshub appears as an established king of the gods whose storm power proves insufficient against primordial inertia, forcing him to rely on ancestral cosmological knowledge to preserve divine order.
The Purulli Ritual Instructions transform Illuyanka from a mythic adversary into a ritualized chaos-force that must be periodically restrained rather than destroyed.
The Myth presents Illuyanka as undefeated chaos in principle, temporarily restrained but never eliminated.
The Song of Ullikummi functions as a sequel to The Song of Kumarbi, shifting mythic focus from succession to the containment of chaos through the stabilization of cosmic order.
The Myth of Illuyanka provides the narrative foundation for the Purulli festival, whose ritual instructions formalize the recurring restoration of cosmic order.
